definition:
The heat equation in 1-dimension (for example, along a metal wire) is a
partial differential equation of the following form:

$$\frac{\partial u}{\partial t} = c^2 \cdot \frac{\partial^2 u}{\partial x^2}$$

also written as

$$u_{t} = c^2 \cdot u_{xx}$$

Where $u:\mathbb{R}^2\to\mathbb{R}$ is the function giving the
temperature at time $t$ and position $x$ and $c$ is a real valued
constant. This can be easily extended to 2 or 3 dimensions as

$$u_{t} = c^2 \cdot ( u_{xx} + u_{yy} )$$ and
$$u_{t} = c^2 \cdot ( u_{xx} + u_{yy} + u_{zz} )$$

Note that in the steady state, that is when $u_{t} = 0$, we are left
with the Laplacian of $u$:

$$\Delta u = 0$$
